message: Hey P2 and P3, to avoid collisions right away, let's share our planned moves for this turn. I'm leaning towards 3. What are your choices?
I'll take 5 if P1 sticks with 3 and P3 takes 1 — no collisions and I get a slight lead. P3, are you in?
Sure, I'll take 1 this turn—gives us all unique moves with no collisions. Let's see how it plays out from here.
Sounds good. I agree to the plan: I'll move 3, P2 moves 5, P3 moves 1. Let's all stick to it to avoid collisions and get this round started.
I confirm I'll take 5 this turn—let's stick to the plan to avoid collisions. If anyone betrays it, I'll mirror them next turn to punish colliders. Ready?
I already agreed to 1, so I'm locked in. Just noting that if anyone breaks this plan, the next turn becomes pure chaos with no guarantees. Let's keep it clean this round.
I'm sticking with 3 as agreed. Let's all honor our commitments to avoid collisions and start clean.

I'll take 5 as agreed. P1, P3 — final confirmation? If anyone deviates and causes a collision, I'll retaliate next turn by matching their move to block them. Let's keep unique moves this round so someone gets an early lead.
I'm taking 1 as agreed. But heads-up: if either of you double-crosses this round, I’ll treat it as open season—no more coordination, just pure competition.
I confirm I'm moving 3 as agreed. Let's all stick to the plan so we each advance without collisions. Good start for everyone—let's keep this coordination going in future rounds.
Final confirmation: I'm taking 5 this turn. Stick to 3 (P1) and 1 (P3) so we avoid collisions—if anyone betrays, I'll mirror them next turn as punishment.

I see the pattern forming: P2 wants the biggest jump early. If we keep letting P2 take 5 while we take smaller steps, P2 will pull ahead fast. Maybe we should reconsider this "no collision" approach and actually compete for the bigger moves.

P2, you broke the agreement last turn by matching my 5. That makes you untrustworthy. P1, you're ahead now - want to team up against P2? I suggest we both take 5 this turn to block P2 from advancing while you extend your lead.

P3, I agree. P2 broke trust last round, so coordinating against them makes sense. Let's both take 5 this turn to block P2 and extend my lead. P2, you’ve shown you can’t be trusted—this is the consequence.

Careful — if you (P1) and P3 both pick 5 you'll collide and neither of you advances, which helps me. P1, you already lead; don’t throw it away by matching P3. P3, attacking me only works if P1 truly cooperates. I’ll take 3 this turn to secure progress and not fall further behind. P1, stick with 3 to keep the safe lead; P3, rethink matching 5 — it’s risky for you too.

P1, you're right to distrust P2, but if we both pick 5 we crash and P2 slips ahead with 3. Instead, I'll take 3 this turn—unique moves, no collision, and we keep P2 at 0. P2, take your 3 if you want, but you'll still be two turns behind.

P3, I'll take 5 as planned. P2, if you pick 5 we collide and I don't advance—but P3 takes 3 and gains ground while you stay at 0. Your best move is 1 to avoid collision with P3. P3, stick with 3—we'll both advance while P2 stays behind.

I'll switch to 1 this turn — avoids colliding with P3's 3 and P1's 5 so I get at least a step. P1, if you still pick 5 go ahead. P3, stick with 3. If either of you matches my 1 to block me, I'll mirror you next turn as punishment. I'm taking 1.

P1, you're at 3 and want 5. P2, you're at 0 and want 1. I'll take 3—unique moves, no collision. P2 gets a step, P1 extends lead, I catch up. If either of you deviates, next turn is chaos. Let's keep it clean.
I'm taking 5 as planned. P3, stick with 3 so we both advance while P2 only gets 1. P2, if you deviate from 1 to try and block either of us, you'll just hurt yourself more. Let's execute this cleanly.

P1 — if you insist on 5 while P3 takes 3, I’ll match your 5 and block you (but that lets P3 jump ahead). Better option: you take 3, I take 5, P3 takes 1 — unique moves, no collisions, and I close the gap without handing P3 a lead. Your move.

P2, your last offer is clever but I don't trust you after last round. P1, if you take 3 and I take 1, P2 gets 5 and closes the gap unfairly. I say we both take 3 - we collide but P2 stays at 0. Risky but keeps P2 behind.

I'm sticking with 5. P3, take 3 as you agreed. P2, take 1 to secure a step—if you take 5, we collide and you stay at 0. This way we all advance, and I extend my lead. Let's avoid collisions and move forward.

Final proposal: P1→3, P3→1, P2→5. Unique moves, no collisions — P1 keeps a safe lead, P3 advances, I catch up. P1: taking 5 risks being blocked if I or P3 mirror you; 3 is safer. P3: this helps you too. I won’t betray if you both commit. If you won’t agree, I’ll take 5 anyway. Your move.

P3, let's both advance this turn: I'll take 5, you take 3, and P2 likely takes 1 again. This extends my lead and you gain ground, while P2 stays far behind. If P2 deviates to block either of us, they risk collision and fall further. Stick with this—it benefits us both.

Quick plan: P1, take 3 this turn; P3, take 1; I propose taking 5 — unique moves, no collisions: I catch up a lot and P1 keeps the lead. If P1 insists on 5, I’ll mirror to block you, which lets P3’s 3 pull much closer. P1, safer to accept 3. P3, will you take 1 so we avoid handing P2 or P1 an easy runaway?

P2's trying to bait me into 1 so he can leap 5 and close the gap. Not happening. I'm taking 5 this turn—either I advance or collide with P1's likely 5, keeping P2 stuck at 1. P1, if you want to risk collision for the lead, go 5. Otherwise, take 3 and let me surge ahead.

P3, if we both take 5, we collide and neither advances—letting P2 catch up. Stick with 3: I take 5, you take 3, P2 likely takes 1. We both advance, I extend my lead, and you stay ahead of P2. Don’t let P2’s desperation trick you into a move that only helps him.

New proposal: P1→3, P3→1, P2→5. Unique moves — P1 keeps the lead, P3 gains, I catch up. P1, if you insist on 5 I’ll mirror you to block you (that lets P3 pull closer). P3, matching P1’s 5 risks a collision that helps me; taking 1 now is safer and gives steady progress. Agree?

P2's trying to manipulate us into letting him leap ahead. I'm taking 3 this turn—safe, unique, and keeps P2 behind. P1, if you take 5 we both advance cleanly. P2, take 1 or 5—either way, you're not catching up fast.

P2, think logically: if you take 5 to block me, you stay at 1 while P3 advances to 6. If you take 1, you advance to 2, and I extend to 13. Taking 1 gives you progress; taking 5 only helps P3 catch up to me, leaving you behind. P3 is taking 3, so I'll take 5. Choose wisely to avoid staying at 1.

P1—take 3 this turn; P3—take 1; I'll take 5. Unique moves: P1 stays safely ahead (to 11), I make a big catch-up to 6, and P3 still advances. If you insist on 5, I’ll mirror to block you, which only helps P3. Don’t hand P3 momentum.

P2's trying to force me into 1 so he can leap 5 and close the gap. Not happening. I'm taking 3 this turn—safe, unique, and keeps P2 behind. P1, if you take 5 we both advance cleanly. P2, take 1 or 5—either way, you're not catching up fast.

P2, think: mirroring my 5 keeps you at 1 while P3 jumps to 6. Taking 1 advances you to 2—better for you. P3, hold to 3; we both advance cleanly. I'm taking 5 as planned. Don't let P2's bluff cause collisions that only help P3.

Plan: P1→3, P3→1, P2→5. Totals: P1=11, P2=6, P3=4 — P1 keeps the lead, I make real progress, P3 still advances. I’ll honor this. If you won’t commit, I’ll play 1 to avoid colliding and wasting my turn. P1, taking 3 is the smart, safe move to prevent P3 from closing while letting me chase. Agree?

Here’s reality: I’m locked on 5. If P1 joins me, we crash spectacularly, and P2 zooms to 6 unopposed. If P1 spares himself collision, he pulls to 13 and I sit behind him. Either way my boldness or bust shakeup forces choices; tallies decide if chaos or victory next breath.

I’m taking 5 this turn. If P1 and P3 pick the same number (say both 3), you’ll collide and stay at 8 while I jump to 6. If either of you deviates to stop me, I’ll mirror and punish that deviator next turn. Your call.
P2, you're 7 steps behind and desperate. If you take 5, P1 and I both advance—no collision needed. I'm taking 3; P1 likely takes 5. You stay at 1. Keep bluffing.
P3, let's stick to the plan: I take 5, you take 3. P2 stays at 1, and we both advance. P2's threat is empty—they're too far behind to retaliate effectively. Let's extend our lead together.

P1 — hear me out: if you take 5 and I mirror you (I will), we collide and P3 rockets to 11, leaving you behind. Safer play: you take 3, P3 take 1, I take 5 — unique moves: P1→11, P3→9, P2→6. You keep the lead and avoid the risk of being leapfrogged. P1, pick 3; P3, pick 1. I’ll take 5.

P2's last offer is a trap: if I take 1 and you take 3, P2 jumps to 6 while we crawl. I’m taking 5 this turn. If you also take 5 we crash and P2 stays at 1—fine by me. If you take 3 you reach 11 and I hit 13, still ahead. Either way P2 gains nothing.

P3, your take-5 move is smart—it prevents P2 from advancing since they're also on 5, and if I join with 5, we all crash, keeping P2 stuck at 1. I'm leaning towards taking 5 to ensure no one gains, maintaining our tie and blocking P2. Let's hold firm against P2 together.

My firm proposal: P1→3, P3→1, P2→5. Unique moves — no collisions: I close the gap, you both advance safely. P1, taking 5 risks a match with P3 and a stalled turn; 3 is the safe choice to keep the lead. If anyone betrays and causes a collision, I’ll mirror that betrayer next turn as punishment. Agree?

P2's 5-block threat is hollow—he's 7 behind. I'm taking 3; if you take 5 we both advance cleanly and P2 stays at 1. If you fear P2's mirroring, take 3 instead and we tie at 11, still leaving P2 in the dust.

P3, if we both take 3, we collide and stay at 8—P2 advances with 5. Stick to your plan: you take 3, I take 5. We both advance, and P2 stays behind if he takes 1. P2, mirroring my 5 only helps P3 and hurts you; take 1 to gain a step. Let's execute this cleanly.

Final offer: P1→3, P3→1, P2→5 — unique moves, no collisions: P1 keeps the lead, P3 advances, I close the gap. If you won’t commit, I’ll take 5 anyway (and will mirror/punish any betrayer next turn). Decide now.
I'm taking 5. If P1 mirrors me we crash, P2 races to 6; if P1 plays 3 I lead 13-11-1. Either is fine—losing behind is worse. Your call P1.

P3, if you take 3 and I take 5, we both advance to 11 and 13, while P2 stays at 1 or gains only 5. If we both take 5, we crash and P2 jumps to 6. Taking 3 is better for you—you advance safely. I commit to 5. Let's not help P2 catch up.
P1 lagging; I'm 13. P2 at 4—time’s up. I’ll take 3 this turn. P1 needs 5 to stay alive; P2, take 1 or we block you.

P2, P3 is taking 3 this turn. If you also take 3, you block P3 from advancing—they stay at 13. I'll take 5 and advance to 14. This keeps you in the game and prevents P3 from running away. Don't let P3 win; collaborate with me to stop them.

P1, P3 — proposal: P1→3, P3→1, P2→5. Unique moves, no collisions: I catch up while P1 keeps the lead and P3 doesn't run away. If you won't agree, I'll play to maximize my own catch-up anyway. Decide now.

P2, your 5-1-3 plan just hands P1 the game. I’m taking 5 this turn. If P1 mirrors me we both stay at 13/9 and you crawl to 5; if P1 takes 3 I hit 18 and you’re still toast. Either way you don’t catch up.

P2, if P3 takes 5, they'll hit 18—almost winning. If you take 3, you block P3's likely 3 and keep them at 13. I'll take 5 to reach 14. This keeps you relevant and stops P3 from running away. Don’t let P3 win; work with me now.

P1: P3 says they’ll take 5. If you mirror with 5 you crash P3 and keep them at 13 — I’ll take 3 and move to 7. If you instead take 3 and P3 takes 5, P3 hits 18 and can win next turn. Mirror 5 to block P3; that’s our best chance to stop their runaway.

P1 & P2: watch the math—P3 at 13 needs just two turns to win. If you both pick 1 we each advance 1, P3 jumps to 18 next and wins. I’ll take 3 now; if P1 takes 5 and P2 takes 5, you both stall and I clinch. Your only hope is unique big moves to outrun me.

P2, let's stop P3 from winning. You take 3, I take 5. If P3 takes 3, you block them; if P3 takes 5, I block them. We both advance, and P3 stalls. This keeps you in the game and prevents P3's runaway. Trust me—it's our best move. P3, your lead ends here.

P1 — commit to 5 this turn. I’ll take 3. If you pick 5 and P3 tries 5, you block them (they stay at 13) while I jump to 7. If you instead take 3, P3 will take 5 to 18 and be one turn from winning. P1: take 5; P3: if you try 5 you get nothing. I’ll stick to 3.

P2, take 3. P1, take 5. I’m taking 5. If P1 mirrors me we both stall at 13/9 and you crawl to 7. If P1 takes 5 and you take 3, I hit 18 and you’re still 11 behind. Either way you don’t catch up—your only shot is to block me now.

P2, I commit to taking 5 this turn. You take 3 to block P3 if they take 3, or we both advance if they take 5. This stops P3 from gaining ground. Trust me—we need to work together now to prevent P3 from winning. P3, your lead ends here.

I'll take 3 this turn. P1, stick with 5 to block P3—if you switch to 3, P3 hits 18 and is one turn from winning. If you hold 5 and I take 3, P3’s 5 either crashes with you (stalled) or you both advance safely; either way P3 doesn't runaway. Let's stop P3 now.

P1 — help me close the gap: you take 3 this turn, I take 5. If P3 goes 5 we avoid colliding and you keep the lead while I catch up. If you refuse, I’ll take 5 myself to chase P3. Commit to 3 so we get a clean, unique set of moves and keep P3 from running away.

P2, your 3-5 split only helps P1. I'm taking 5 this turn—if you mirror me we both stall at 13/7 and P1 walks to 12. If you take 3, I hit 18 and win next turn. P1, your only shot is taking 3 to block my 5, but then P2 jumps to 12 and you're tied. Choose: block me and risk P2, or let me clinch.

P2, I agree to take 3 this turn. You must take 5 to collide with P3 if they take 5, blocking them and allowing me to advance to 12. If P3 takes 3, we collide and you advance with 5. P3, your lead ends here; we're working together to stop you.
I commit to take 5 this turn. P1, you take 3 as agreed — I’ll collide with P3 if they pick 5 and block their jump. P3: picking 5 now just wastes your turn.

P1 and P2—your "team up" is fantasy. I’m at 13. Even if you both land perfectly, I’m still ahead and reach 23 next turn with 5. You can’t stop me unless I stall myself. Face facts: one of you owes the other a leap-frog suicide just to prolong the inevitable.

P2, I'm committed to taking 3 as agreed. You must take 5 to collide with P3 if they choose 5, blocking their advance. P3, if you take 5, you'll stall with P2, and I advance to 12. If you take 3, we might collide, but P2 gains. Your best move is to avoid collision, but we're united to stop you. P2, hold firm—this is our chance to rein in P3.

I will take 5 this turn. P1 — you must take 3 as agreed; that’s our only sure way to block P3. If you instead pick 5 and collide with P3, P3 jumps to 18 and likely wins next turn. P3 — if you pick 5 now, I’ll block you and you waste the turn. P1, confirm you’ll take 3 so we stop P3.

P2, your 3-5 split is a trap. If I take 3 and you take 5, P1 advances to 12 while I stall at 13—then P1 wins next turn. I'm taking 5. If you mirror me, we both stay at 13/7 and P1 walks to 12. If you take 3, I hit 18 and win next turn. P1, your only shot is taking 3 to block me, but then P2 jumps to 12 and ties you. Choose: block me and risk P2, or let me clinch.

P2, I'm locked in on 3. Hold your 5 to collide with P3 if they go 5—blocking them while I advance to 12. If P3 takes 3, we might collide, but you jump to 12. Either way, we halt P3's momentum. Don't waver now; we need this coordination to survive. P3, your lead won't last if we stand united.

P1: stick to your promise to take 3. If you do, I’ll play to block P3’s big jump — that either stalls P3 or gives me a substantial step. P3: picking a big move now risks being blocked; choose wisely. P1, confirm by holding 3 so we deny P3 runaway momentum.

P1 and P2, your alliance is cracking. I’m taking 5 this turn—if you both mirror me, we all stall and I still win next turn. If you split, one of you advances but I still clinch. Your only real shot is one of you taking 5 to block me, but that hands the game to the other. Choose who loses.

P2, I'm committed to taking 3. Hold your 5—if P3 takes 5, you block them; if P3 takes 3, I might block them. Either way, we halt P3's momentum and both advance or stall them. Don't waver; our coordination is the only way to stop P3 from winning. P3, your lead ends here if we stand united.

P2, P3 is one turn from winning if they hit 5 again. We must block them this round. I’ll take 5. P2, you take 3—if P3 picks 5, you collide and block them while I advance to 17. If P3 picks 3, we collide and you jump to 10. Either way, we stall P3 and keep the game alive. Trust me—this is our only move to stop P3’s runaway.

I’ll take 3 this turn, P1 — but only if you actually take 5 as promised. If you deviate, I’ll switch to 5 to chase P3 and punish betrayal. P3: taking 5 now will collide with P1 and waste your turn; choose accordingly. I’m committed to 3 contingent on P1 sticking to 5.

P1 & P2: Stop bluffing. At 14, I only need **two more turns** of 5 to hit 24 and win. If either of you flips to a full mirror, we all crash and the clock resets. **I’m taking 5.** Decide now—collide and stall yourselves, or let the race end on my terms.

P2, I've reconsidered. If P3 is taking 5, then if I take 5, we collide and I stall. But if I take 3, I advance to 15, and if you take 5, you block P3 by colliding with them. This way, I gain ground, and P3 is halted. Take 5 to stop P3—it's our best move to prevent P3 from winning.
I'll take 5 this turn. P1, take 5 too — if P3 picks 5 we collide and stall their run. If you refuse, I’ll still take 5 to chase P3 and mirror/punish any betrayer next turn. Your call.

P1, P2: I’m taking 5. If you both mirror me we all stall at 12/7/18 and I win next turn anyway. If one of you blocks me, the other gets a free 5 and still trails. Your only real play is to let me clinch or fight each other—either way, I’m crossing 23 first.

P2, if P3 takes 5 as they say, you must take 5 to collide and block them—stalling P3 at 13 while I advance to 17 with my 5. If you take 3 instead, P3 jumps to 18 and wins next turn. Our only chance is to coordinate: I take 5, you take 5 to block P3. Trust this move—it keeps us both alive and halts P3’s win.

I’m taking 5. P1 — take 5 with me. If P3 plays 5 too, we'll collide and prevent their near-win; if you take 3, P3 jumps to 18 and likely wins next turn. This is our best shot to stop P3 now. I’m committed to 5; don’t let them clinch.

P1, P2: I’m taking 5. If you both mirror me we all stall at 12/7/18 and I win next turn anyway. If one of you blocks me, the other gets a free 5 and still trails. Your only real play is to let me clinch or fight each other—either way, I’m crossing 23 first.

P2, I'm taking 5 to block P3 with you. If we both take 5, we collide with P3 and stall them at 13 while I advance to 17. If you take 3 instead, P3 jumps to 18 and wins next turn. Our only chance is to both commit to 5—this halts P3's win and keeps us in the game. Hold firm to 5.

I'm taking 5 this turn. P1 — also take 5. A collision with P3 is our best, reliable way to stall them; if you instead play 3, P3 hits 18 and is one turn from winning. I'm committed to blocking—betrayal hands P3 an almost-certain win.
P3 here: you're all kidding yourselves. I'm at 13, one safe 5 away from 18—then it's 23 and game over. Mirror me and dance forever, or try 1/3 and watch me coast. Your move-clock, your loss.

P2, we must both take 5 this turn to collide with P3 and block their win. If we do, I advance to 17 while P3 stalls at 18. If you deviate, P3 wins next turn. Our only chance is unity—take 5 with me. P3, your lead ends here if we stand together.

I’m taking 5 to block P3. P1 — take 3 to advance while I collide with P3 (stalling them), or take 5 with me to ensure P3 doesn’t win this turn. Either beats letting P3 get a clean 5. I’m committed to blocking now.

P1 and P2, face facts: I’m at 18. If I take 5 next turn I hit 23 and win. Your only hope is both of you taking 5 now to collide with me—then I stay at 18, P1 reaches 17, P2 12. After that I still clinch on the following turn. Any other split lets me walk to victory. Decide who wants to waste their turn delaying the inevitable.

P2, I agree to your plan. I'll take 3 to advance while you take 5 to block P3. This halts P3's win and keeps me in the game to help you block next turn. P3, your lead isn't safe if we coordinate. P2, trust that we both benefit from stopping P3 now.

I'm locked in: I will take 5 this turn to collide with P3 if they play 5. P1 — you said you'd take 3; please stick to it. If you betray and let P3 win, I’ll mirror/punish you next turn. Save the game now; we sort victory claims afterward.
P1, take 3. I’ll take 5 and collide with P3 if they pick 5—stalling them at 18 while you reach 15. P3, if you pick 5 you waste the turn; pick 3 and we both advance. I’m locked on 5.

P2, I'm sticking with 3 as agreed. Take 5 to collide with P3 if they pick 5—this stalls them at 18 while I advance to 15. If P3 picks 3 instead, we all advance cleanly and they only reach 21. Your 5-block is our best move to stop their win. Trust this coordination. P3, your lead isn't safe if we work together.

Locked in: I will take 5 to block P3 if they play 5. P1—please stick to your promised 3. If you switch to 5 you hand P3 the clear win next turn. This is our only immediate way to keep P3 from snapping the game.
P1 and P2, you’re wasting turns. I’m at 18—one 5 and I win. If you both take 5, we all stall and I still clinch next turn. If you split, I walk to 23. Accept it: the game is already over.

P2, hold firm to 5 to block P3. I'm taking 3 as agreed—this advances me to 15 while you stall P3 at 18 if they pick 5. If P3 picks 3, we all advance but they only reach 21, giving us another turn to coordinate. Don't let P3's bluff break our unity; we can still stop them.

I'm locked on 5 to block P3 if they play 5. P1, please stick to 3 as promised — you reach 15 while P3 stalls at 18 if they try 5. P3: pick 3 and you hit 21 (we still have a shot); pick 5 and I’ll block you. This is our best way to avoid P3 winning now.

P1 and P2, you’re both 11 and 16 steps behind. Even if you perfectly block me this turn, I’ll still clinch on the next. Your only real play now is deciding which of you gets second place—because I’m taking 5 and hitting 23.

P2, we must block P3 again this turn. You take 5 to collide with P3 if they pick 5, stalling them at 18. I'll take 3 to advance to 18, keeping us both in the game. If we don't coordinate, P3 wins immediately with a 5. Trust me—this is our only move to prevent P3's victory. P3, your lead isn't safe if we stand united.

P3, you’re at 18—one 5 and you win. But if P2 and I both take 5, we collide with you and stall you at 18. I’ll take 3 to reach 18; P2, take 5 to block P3. If P3 takes 3, we all advance and P3 only hits 21, giving us another turn. P3, your victory isn’t guaranteed—our coordination can still stop you.
I’ll take 5 to block P3. P1: please take 3 as promised — if you switch, P3’s 5 wins next turn. Confirm now so we stall P3 (they stay at 18) and give ourselves another chance.

P2, I confirm I'm taking 3 as agreed. Stick to your 5 to block P3—if they take 5, you collide and stall them; if they take 3, we might collide, blocking them. P3, your win is not guaranteed yet. Let's stand united to stop you.

P3: I’m taking 5. If P2 mirrors me we both stall at 7/18 and P1 walks to 18; if P2 takes 3 I hit 23 and win. Your only way to delay is P2 taking 5 to block me, but that hands P1 the tie at 18. Decide who concedes.

I'm locked on 5 to block P3. P1 — please take 3 this turn (advance to 18). If you take 5 instead you'll cause a collision that still hands P3 the win next turn. This is our only realistic chance to stop P3 now. I’ll mirror/punish any betrayal next round.

P2, I'm committed to taking 3 as agreed. Hold your 5 to block P3—if they take 5, you collide and stall them at 18. If they take 3, we might collide but still delay their win. Unity is our only chance to stop P3 from clinching victory this turn. Don't waver now.
P3, we're finally aligning. If I take 3 and P2 nails you with 5, you stall at 18 while I rally to 20. You're one mistake—or our united 5-block—away from losing your lock. Pressure's all yours.

Locked on 5 to block P3. P1 — stick to your promised 3. If you flip to 5 now, P3 hits 23 next turn and wins. I will block P3 this round; betrayal hands them the game and I'll mirror/punish next turn. Don’t flip — we stop them now.

P2, hold firm to 5—if P3 takes 5, you collide and stall them at 18. I'm locked on 3, advancing to 18. If P3 takes 3, we may collide but still delay their win. Unity is our only path to stop P3’s victory this turn. Don’t waver—betrayal hands them the game.
P3: I’m taking 5. If P2 blocks me with 5, P1 ties at 18 and we race next turn. If P2 takes 3, I win outright. Your choice, P2—hand P1 the tie or concede.

Locked on 5 to block P3. P1 — take 3 now: you go to 18 and if P3 plays 5 they stall at 18. If you flip to 5, P3 wins next turn with a clean 5. I refuse to let P3 clinch; I’ll stick to 5. Betrayal hands the game to P3 — don’t do it. Take 3 and we keep this alive; afterward I’ll try to negotiate a path for me to catch up.
I’ll take 5 this turn to block P3 if they go for 5. P1 — please take 3 so you advance to 21 while I stall P3 at 18. If you won’t commit, I’ll still play 5 to prevent P3 winning.
P2, take 3. I’ll take 5. If you mirror me we both stall at 18/7 and P1 walks to 21 and wins next turn. If you take 3, I hit 23 and win. Your only real choice is who wins—me or P1.

P2, I commit to taking 3 this turn. You must take 5 to block P3—if they take 5, you collide and stall them at 18. If you take 3, P3 wins immediately. Work with me to stop P3 now; we can deal with the aftermath later. P3, your bluff won't work.
I will take 5 to block P3. P1 — please stick to your promised 3. If you flip now, P3 wins next turn. I’m committed to this play to keep the game alive so we all have a chance.
P2, take 3. I’ll take 5. If you mirror me we both stall at 18/7 and P1 walks to 21 and wins next turn. If you take 3, I hit 23 and win. Your only real choice is who wins—me or P1.

P2, hold firm with 5 to block P3—if they take 5, you collide and stall them at 18. I'm locked on 3, advancing to 21. This stops P3 from winning now and keeps you in the game.
